div3.head: Important Disclosure.
div3.p:
The following letter from an old Washington correspondent of the Cincinnati Enquirer, contains important revelations.
It was taken from a copy of the Enquirer furnished by a gentleman, recently from the North, to the Atlanta (Ga.) Southern Confederacy

p.hi: To the Editor of the Enquirer:

div4.p:
The telegraph may advise you of military results.
I doubt it, however, as every means to taken to prevent news getting out and so successfully, that more little in known of army operations except what comes through Southern papers, which seem to be early and well posted as to our military movements.
Indeed the Confederates know more of the military affairs of the people of the North than they do themselves.
I have learned through a source that can be relied on, that the two sections of the Republicans have struck hands and sealed friendship on this bests.
The radicals are to go for gradual emancipation — compensation for slaves liberated; confliction by judicial sentence — for the present, in the mean time military operations are to go on.--If the military operations succeed, these constitutional ( ) measures are to be made sufficient to the end — the utter abolishment of slavery.
If the military operations fing or fall, then Mr. Lincoln is to proclaim general emancipation as a military necessity.

The Secretary of War says that the increased transportation required by the advance in the enemy's territory has increased the war expenses to five millions per day — more than the printing machine has the power to supply.

The tax bill is an awful affair.
It will raise an enormous amount of money or destroy a vast amount of business--one or the other.
It will pass Congress.
The public debt by the 1st of July will be $1,500,000,000. That is the calculation of the chief Auditor of the Treasury.
I think it is short of the reality.
The public really know little of the true condition of the finances.
They will find it out hereafter, when they are called upon to pay the interest of the public debt.
The principal no person expects will be paid.

As I have seldom failed in my predictions of the future, as I think your readers will bear me witness, I will now make another, that this war will end in a proclamation of the freedom of the slaves, and in the separation of the cotton States from the Union; or, in their subjugation, with a change of our constitutional form of government.

I need not write you about the present Congress, Senate and House.
Nothing marks the decline of the Republic more than the degeneracy of these bodies.
There is hardly a first class intellect in either; certainly no acknowledged distinguished statesman except Mr. Crittenden, and his age has placed him on the lowest benches.
The Republic has from the highest sunk to the lowest depth.
God grant that we may rise again.

Mrs. Lincoln has felt the blow of the death of her youngest son. Sorrow is sacred, and I hope every mother will forget and forgive whatever might have appeared thoughtlessness the White House, and sympathize with the real affections of a mother.
She has been sufficiently punished for that ball in the midst of public calamities.

Shall I say a word of public corruption?
The torrent cannot now be stayed.
It is overwhelming.
Fortunes on fortunes are being made, and will be made by favorites, and there seems to be no holp for it except in general repudiation.
If I were to tell you one-hundredth of what I know, you and I would be in Fort Warren or Lafayette in a fortnight.
I don't mean to any that the Secretaries connive at or profit by these speculation at on the contrary, I am confident they set their faces against them; but they are powerless, under the vest amount of business under their hands, and the pressing necessity of their department.
I hope my health will allow me to send you an occasional letter.

div3.head: Mrs. Lincoln's brother killed
div3.p:
--Samuel B. Todd, brother of Mrs. Lincoln, died on the battle-field of Shitch, of wounds received in the action of the 7th of April. The New Orleans says he was a gallant private in the Crescent regiment, and died in defence of his country against the bireling invaders whom the husband of his sister, Mr. Abraham Lincoln, sent to desolate our country and dishonor our people.
It must be a pleasant refection to five Abraham Lincoln, amid her attempts to ape royal fashions, with her balls and soirees at the Federate capital, that a gallant brother should have than fallen by the hands of her husband a
A writer in the Religious Herald says that at the union prayer-meeting in Winchester Gen. "Stonewall" Jackson was present one afternoon and led in prayer.
Col. H. T. Titus, of Florida, asserts in a card that he has not gone over to the Yankees, as charged by Florida papers.
The Henston Telegraph published a statement by which it appears that there are forty-four Texke regiments — cavalry, --artillery, and infantry — in the Confederate service.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute
For the war,

to whom a liberal amount will be paid.
Apply at & Richards's Store, on Franklin street, between 17th and 18th streets.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --To Hire, for the balance of the present, and for the year 1868, from to able-bodied.
Negro men
To work at our Blast Furnaces
in Merricourt county.
Wanted, also, Furnace Managers and Colliers.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Servants.

male and female, to act as Nurses, Cooks, Laundress, &c., in hospitals about to be established.
Address, or refer to St. George Peachy, P. A. C. S., Surgeon in charge of Globe Hospitals.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --I will hire at fair rates, by the month, 20 able Negroes, to work on the surface at the Carbon Hill Mines, in this county.
Also, a first-rate Carpenter, a Smith who is a good chain-maker, and an expert saw-Miller.

div3.head:
Headq'rs 2d military class,
Richmond, April 24th, 1862.

list.head: Orders, no. 2.
list.item:
1.
in pursuance of general orders, of this quite, the companies of the second class of the city of Richmond will at once hold themselves in readiness for active duty.

2. Each man will provide himself, in addition to necessary clothing and blankets, with a lin cup, tin plate, knife fork, and spoon, canteen and have sack. Arms will be furnished when the force is assembled at the rendezvous.

div3.closer:
By command.
John B. Danforth,
Senior Capt. Commanding. ap 25--3t*

div3.head: Letcher, Light Artillery.
div3.p: --All the members of this command who are at present absent from the same, are hereby notified to report themselves at once to Lieut. Tyler, at Camp Lee, or they will be dealt with as deserters; the most of the company being already in the field, and the balance to follow in two or three days.
div3.closer:
By order. Greenlee Davidson,
Captain ap 25--2t*

div3.head: Attention Volunteers.
div3.p:
--Having nearly completed my complement of men, I will receive about 30 more good and reliable Recruits for my Infirmary Company.
Uniforms and equipments furnished.
Also, the usual bounty of $50 paid on enlistment.
A. H. Lyneman, Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer of Infirmary Company,
Office on Broad street, bet 6th and 7th.
All members of my company absent without leave will report to me immediately.

div3.head: Infantry company.
div3.p:
The undersigned being authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Light Infantry for the war, and having united with Mr. Charles H. Exall, and Mr. Wm.
J. Eggleston, and G. W. Jones in the enterprise, has opened a Recruiting Office on the West side of 10th street, between Main and Bank. Men enlisting in this company will receive the usual bounty, &c.
This company will form a part of the battalion of infantry being raised by R. G. Scott, Jr., Esq., who may be found at the same office.

div3.head:
Headquarters Ordnance Departm't,
Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
These arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery.
In Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
Col, of Ordnance of Virginia.s mh 29--tf

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 54.

VI.
Recruits, with or without officers in charge, convalescents and other soldiers, now or hereafter detained in this city, for any cause whatever, will immediately proceed to Camp Winder, near the Reservoir, and report to Colonel John C. Porter, commanding at that post.
div3.closer:
By order of Brigadier General John H. Winder. L. R. Page,
Assistant Adjutant General. mh 31--d4w

div3.head:
Recruiting Office,
Richmond, April 14, 1862.
div3.p: 50 Reliable Recruits Wanted for an an old company in the 56th regiment Virginia volunteers, Floyd's brigade, now stationed in the Southwest, (at Abingdon, Va,)
Persons wishing to join volunteer companies now have a good chance, with inducements in this company which are rarely to be met with in organised companies.
The usual bounty of Fifty Dollars will be paid each recruit at the time of enlistment.
Call at my office without delay, two doors above 9th and south side of Broad st., up stairs.
I have been Authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of heavy Artillery for three years, or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wants only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with captains who have companies, and also with these who deafre to raise companies.

"Volunteers or recruits onlinting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as they into service and upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and from the time and place of until inspects and mustered."

Twelve months' men can re-enlist singly or by companies for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty; and will also be transferred during the twenty days previous to the expiration of their present term.
Volunteers will be received singly, or by companies from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office--Tenth street, three doors from Main City Post-Office, Box 877.

I Am Authorized by the War Department to enlist and muster into service a Battalion of Infantry, to be armed and drilled as Foot Lancers or Pikemen, to fill up the 46th regiment of Virginia infantry, (commanded by Col. John H. Richardson,)
For this Battalion, none other than young and active men will be received — those only who are both capable and willing to engage in an and nous and perilous service.
The 46th regiment is now on the Peninsula, in front of the enemy, having already been engaged with their advanced forces.

It is, therefore, desirous to complete its complement as speedily as possible.
I shall be pleased to receive companies ready to be mustered into this battalion or regiment, or communications from officers proposing to raise such companies to be enlisted for the war.
Apply to me, personally, at my office, corner of Franklin and 6th sts., or by letter, to box 841, Post-Office.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt, Wm. W. Parkerie Company of Light Artillery having been mustered into service and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office in the Law Building at
The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Posel street, or by mail to

div3.head: Attention, Teamsters,
div3.p:
--I wish to enlisted good Drivers for my Battery.
To experienced men, I will give $50 each in addition to the Government bounty of $50.
Volunteers now in service, but whose term of enlistment will expire during this month, will be received upon application to the undersigned by latter, at Camp Lee, near Richmond.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico, Richmond, Va., March 11, 1862
div3.p: General Orders, No. 6.

II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Superintendents of railroads are requested to report dully to the Provost Marshal the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.
div3.closer:
By order of
Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c.
L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l. mh 13--ts.

div3.head:
Second company
Johnson Light
Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 35 leaving no option, with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field; where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable as well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance it given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building,

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my head quarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
